feed.title: Category: day-in-my-life-as-entrepreneur | Blog of Alex Oberhauser

entry.title:
A day in my life as an entrepreneur:
The Year 2013...
entry.content:
The year is nearly finished that means it is a good time to look back and evaluate and asses the achievements. 2013 was an amazing year with a lot of changes and visible results, but also with a lot of challenges and hard work. The following list outlines the most important and biggest milestones this year.

1. Milestone: New Product ‘Campaign Management with Bitcoins’

With the beginning of this year we have started with a new idea to improve donations with the help of bitcoins. In the meantime we have left the prototype phase and working now on a first minimum viable product aka. MVP. This MVP will be used for the pilot phase, with selected users, starting in the first quarter of 2014. The new product is not only usable for donations, but also for all other money acquisition or transaction handling tasks. Stay tuned for this service. It will change the way you think about donations, crowd-funding and related campaign management.

2. Milestone: Sigimera Ltd. was founded

The new product from the first milestone (see above) has resulted in the company formation of Sigimera Ltd. This step should improve trust in our products, but also allows us to provide sophisticated support and services to business and private customers. Sigimera Ltd. will also develop the Crises Information Platform further and combine it with our other services.

3. Milestone: Sigimera expands to Amsterdam

My personal move to Amsterdam, Netherlands had the purpose to push the company, but also to continue my studies at the VU Amsterdam. The main motivation behind the decision was not only to push the company, but also to promote our products and services. For me personally that means that I search now actively for cooperation’s and that I improve my academic, but also my soft-skills.

Do you want to reach Sigimera in Amsterdam? Please feel free to contact me personally.

4. Milestones: Sigimera Ltd. Cooperation’s

Especially to mention this year is that we have cooperated with different external parties and will continue this next year. For example the Windows Phone App for our Crises Information Platform was developed by a Software Engineer from the Microsoft Student Partner program (thank you Asma Bhatti). Additional a student team at the VU Amsterdam works currently together with us on a channel recommendation algorithm for our Campaign Management with Bitcoins product. Also not to forget are the different startups and private persons that participate in our upcoming pilot phase. Thank you guys!

I wish you all nice holidays and a good new year.

entry.title:
A day in my life as an entrepreneur:
Sigimera Ltd. in Amsterdam
entry.content:
It is more than a month ago, I published the last blog post. Let me get you updated what happened during this time. There were two major, somehow interconnected, changes. The first is the move of myself to Amsterdam (the rest of the team stays in Austria and the company legal residence in the UK). The second is the decision to stop all marketing activities and get back to the drawing board. In this blog post I will try to explain to you why this decisions were made and what consequences they have.

Let me start with my move to Amsterdam. I will continue there with my Master studies at the VU Amsterdam, but that is only half of the truth. The other is that I will try to get in touch with the startup community. Not so much through startup events, but more directly with other entrepreneurs, at least for now. That was also the reason why I was in the last few weeks busy with the move and the restructuring of our communication means. As I have explained in one of my last blog post the team is the most crucial part, one reason more to continue with our internal meetings, nevertheless where we are. Until now that works pretty well… Actually better as all other video conferences before. The reason is the fast Internet connection and the updated equipment for this purpose.

The consequence for Sigimera Ltd. is that we have now an unofficial office in Amsterdam. One advantage is the direct connection to one of the biggest Internet Exchange point worldwide. Additional it extends our on-site impact to yet another country. One change was also the restructuring of our telephone system. Now we have a landline phone number in the Netherlands. This number can and will be redirect to all (or some) of our business partners, nevertheless where they are currently and without additional costs for the caller. This phone number allows us to travel around the world and get all calls without roaming costs. If necessary we will get other numbers in the countries where we are active. This is a big advantage for such a company as Sigimera Ltd. We have currently no official office and are spread across two to four countries (until now), nevertheless we are able to communicate in a cheap and reliable way with all stakeholders. Combined with other communication means, e.g. for weekly internal meetings, code quality and software planning platforms, this makes our company structure very flexible and lets us adapt to the ever changing market.

Now that we have a flexible company structure that allows us to communication across country borders and work together in collaborative way, it is time to focus on our business idea. The current plan is to go one or two steps back, stop the past marketing efforts for the Donation Service and build on top of this Donation Service a campaign management system. This extends not only our target market, but gives us also a little bit time to stabilize our company structure and maybe get new business partner. If you have worried in the past weeks if Sigimera is alive, I can you assure that it is and that more than ever.

As you can see we are no conventional company and are able to organize our structures on the go, as every startup should. Our flexibility and commitment to our ideas gives as good base for further development.

As always please let me know what you think. Do you face the same challenges? How do you solve them? What do you think about startup without office space? Looking forward to an interesting conversation and discussion.

entry.title:
A Day in My Life as an Entrepreneur:
It's all about the team
entry.content:
In order to be ready for the challenges as entrepreneur I try to learn as much as possible from different sources. One, very useful, source was, and is, the uprise and most time also downfall of other startups. One important thing that I have learned is that a startup is all about the people. With the right people you get the right know-how and the right environment to overcome the biggest challenges.

If you have not the right people for the right job you will fail. Right is more about attitude as about academic skills. Don’t get me wrong, academic skills are a must, but everybody in your team should be able to get them on the go. As described in previous posts you have to extend your skills outside your field of expertise. It helps if you have a heterogeneous team that is able to exchange knowledge. Develop your expertise the same way as you would develop software in an agile way. The following steps are a simplified way how such a process for knowledge exchange can look like:

  1. Define a challenge that you want solve, e.g. with a clear problem statement
  2. Learn as much as possible about this topic.
  3. Listen and discuss with people around you, maybe you have an expert in your team or you can get feedback from somebody outside.
  4. Evaluate all knowledge that (you think) you have about this topic.
  5. If your knowledge is sufficient to solve the challenge you are good, otherwise get back to point 3.

As you can see you extend your skills in an iterative way. The most important, but also hardest part is point 4. Nobody likes to admit that he or she is wrong or that the own knowledge is not accurate or incomplete. But without acknowledging your failures you are not able to learn, at least not so fast as you could. To be honest I am not as good as I should with this point, but I try to get better each day.

Now we know how we can improve our skills via knowledge exchange. This makes us to an important member of our team. But what is about the right attitude? My personal feeling is that the right attitude is crucial to survive, at least for a young startup. It is the breeding ground for innovation. Do you really want to be part of an startup? The right answer should be YES, at least for a few years. You should not miss this opportunity.

It can be a roller coaster ride, with a lot of downs and ups, especially if you have to motivate yourself each single day… But it is definitely worth it. You invest a few years of your life to learn and improve your skills and not to forget your personality… hopefully to something better. Dependent on your goals you have maybe also a positive impact on your society. We all are getting older each day and our priorities change. This is also the reason why I have decided to take the chance to be an entrepreneur now and for the next few years. Independent if it succeeds or fails I will shift for sure to a more stable life in a later point in time, but I definitely don’t want to miss the possibility to be an entrepreneur.

Please let me know in the comments or via other means how you motivate yourself and your team. Looking forward to other views about this topic.

entry.title:
A day in my life as an entrepreneur:
The Motivation
entry.content:
After the first post in this series – The Beginning – I was asked to write something about my motivation and how my days look like. Where should I start… Do you don’t dream about working without breaks 24/7 and have a job where you don’t get money, but you have to pay for it… Really not!?! Then maybe the profession of an entrepreneur is not the right choice for you. At least not in the startup boostrap phase.

But let me explain what my personal motivation is. As described in the last post I have started with small projects during my studies. The motivation there was to deepen my knowledge in a practical way. Pretty fast this attitude has developed further to see how far I can go. In the beginning it was only about programming software, but after a while I have developed this further to software engineering and how I can organize the programming more effective. During this time I have also researched what is needed for a company formation. This knowledge was really handy this year, by far not complete, but handy.

And what is the motivation today? Of course the experience that you get and the diversity of knowledge that is needed is one of the main reasons. You learn nearly each day something new. But maybe more important is the fun that it makes to build something from scratch. If something does not work… You change it. If you are stuck with something… You switch temporary to another task and return later to this challenging issue. Additional the gained experience helps to overcome harder times. It helps also that our company should have a social impact. I wouldn’t say it is easier to do something good, but it lets you sleep better and it motivates.

Motivation is essential, but how does my day look like? It is maybe more flexible as the average person’s working day. I work when I am ready and not when I must, at least not for my company. I try to combine as much as possible and interconnect tasks. This safes time. Additional I have developed a feeling when I have to stop working on a task where I am stuck. Experience shows that if I come back later I find by far faster a solution as working without break on it. Each software developer experiences sooner or later that he or she has broken more things than fixed if forced to work on a problem at the wrong time. This costs in the long term more time as it safes. We all know it deep inside. What additional helps is that most skills learned in computer science are applicable for other areas as well. This makes the switch to other areas not as hard as it seams. And that is crucial for entrepreneurship. You can’t say I don’t do that, because I am only a software engineer or a XYZ, or whatever your profession is. If you and your team don’t tackle the challenges who else should!?!

Not convinced yet? I have one last motivation that sounds naive, but that should not scare you too much. Calculated naivety is a powerful tool.

If everybody thinks that he or she is to stupid, to weak, to unimportant, or whatever to have an impact and change the world, who the hell dictates your day-to-day life? If you think about it a company is in our society the perfect mean to have an impact. Also if you fail it is always better than not to have tried. I take my chance… What about you?

A journey of a thousand miles begins with a single step.
by Lao-tzu, The Way of Lao-tzu

entry.title:
A day in my life as an entrepreneur:
The Beginning
entry.content:
This is the first post in the series A day in my life as an entrepreneur. In this series I will share my experience how it feels to be an entrepreneur and what challenges we face in our day-to-day work. This is basically the story of my company Sigimera Ltd. and how we survive outside the big startup hubs. Although we profit from the current startup hype around the world we are currently not directly part of it. But lets start from the beginning a few years ago…

All started 5 years ago during a dark and stormy winter night in an even darker cellar… No, just kidding! The time span ago is approximately true, although it is always hard to say, because you don’t wake up and say: “Today I start my new life as entrepreneur!”. The rest is made up. Not all stereotypes are true. Nevertheless… Around this time I have started my first smaller projects and a short time period after, it was clear that I want to start my own company, in order to professionally support this projects. I should mention that I have a background in business and studied at that time computer science at the University of Innsbruck. This is a powerful combination that helps, but is not needed, so don’t be afraid. During this time I have exploited different technologies and switched pretty often between projects. The time was not right for the one big project to rule them all. This was the first phase were I have learned my craft and invested a lot of time to get the basic right and this approach has never changed. Never stop learning!!! Additional it was useful that I owned the domain networld.to and one server. With this basic infrastructure I was able to setup a first working environment used for the software development and get a feeling about workflows and what works and what doesn’t for our team.

Now that I have bored you enough let me know in the comments what you expect from such a series of blog post. Should I continue in chronologically order? Or should I move to the present and write from time to time flashbacks? Do you want know something special? Every feedback is really appreciated.
